results.title: Australian report
results.creator_credit: David Eastman, Ian Hart, Keith Gow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A lighthearted look at Australia in 1973 - its history, industry and tourist attractions. Commments upon the high degree of urbanisation, the enormous mineral reserves and industrial growth and the opportunities which exist for vacationers in both rural and coastal areas. Also looks at the breakdown of isolation through instant electronic communications and air travel. No other credits available.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Eastman, Ian Hart, Keith Gow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Plagued. Episodes 3 & 4
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Edward Goldwyn, Deanne Edwards, Janet Bell, Channel Four, Film Australia and Goldwyn Associates
results.brief_description: Invisible armies examines infectious diseases and how they have been carried around the world as cultures come into contact with each other, and also how some previously eliminated diseases, such as measles and TB, are making a comeback in the western world because of carelessness about immunisation programs. Diseases discussed include syphilis, malaria and smallpox. “Will we ever learn?” Never before have we had such powerful weapons against disease but the tendency to depend on them too much has led to a philosophy of cure rather than prevention. The program looks at AIDS, syphilis and diseases associated with tobacco use and salt. Norman Swan wrote and narrates this thought provoking series, which contends that the real causes of epidemics are social forces.

results.title: Plagued. Episodes 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Edward Goldwyn, Deanne Edwards, Janet Bell, Channel Four, Film Australia and Goldwyn Associates
results.brief_description: Conceived, written and narrated by award winning medical broadcaster, Dr. Norman Swan, this four part series investigates the relationship between history, destiny and disease. “The Origins of disease” investigates, through various case studies, including Korean haemorrhagic fever, shell shock, RSI and heart disease, how new diseases arise. We also discover that some are not diseases at all, but suffering made worse by factors as diverse as medical jargon and management style. “Epidemics: products of progress” takes up the theme that, ironically, throughout history, epidemics have been the results of so-called progress, and that despite medical technology, we are still vulnerable to old and new diseases, such as plague, cholera and AIDS which have the power to change the course of history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aviva Ziegler, Edward Goldwyn, Deanne Edwards, Janet Bell, Channel Four, Film Australia and Goldwyn Associates

results.title: Australian diary. No. 012
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The following items are shown in this interesting cinemagazine: logging red gum on the Murray; Youth and Fitness Week in Melbourne; transferring the Australian scene to textiles and the different codes of football found in Australia.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 083
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The following items are featured in this interesting cinemagazine: members of the Cliff Rescue Squad receive hard training for their hazardous work; the development of the automobile industry is a higlight in Australian progress; Queensland’s Gold Coast with its surf beaches and warm sunshine is developing as a Pacific playground.

results.title: Pacific terminal
results.creator_credit: Commonwealth Department of Information and Government of NSW
results.brief_description: A survey of the capital city of New South Wales, Sydney on Port Jackson. Includes aerial footage of Sydney; monuments in Macquarie Place; inland footage of shearers and bullocks hauling logs; and Australians enjoying a range of recreational activities.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 013
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This newsreel looks at Grafton in New South Wales - a centre of progress and culture. The shape of things to come in glass is highlighted. Experiments with lucerne demonstrate its amazing growth. The Sydney Harbor Bridge is painted and Armidale University is shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board

results.title: The Lord Mayor
results.creator_credit: Chris McGill, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Who is at the centre of the administration of a big city? With this film the viewer spends a day in the company of the Lord Mayor of Sydney, Alderman Sir Nicholas Shehadie, OBE. Narrated by John Laws.
